Description: A ridge of jagged rock, coral, or sand just above or below the surface of the sea.
A type of plant that has feather-like leaves and reproduces via spores, often found in moist, forest settings.
The pointed top of a mountain.
A narrow valley, especially in Scotland.
A small island or peninsula, especially a scenic one.
A small body of still water formed naturally or by artificial means.
A small stream or brook.
A mound or ridge of sand formed by the wind, usually along the beach or in a desert.
A small, green, non-flowering plant that grows in dense clumps or mats, often in damp or shady locations.
A steep rock face, especially at the edge of the sea.
A small, sheltered bay on the coast.
The outer protective layer of a tree's trunk.
The flat, typically green part of a plant, attached to a stem.
A slight obscuration of the lower atmosphere, typically caused by fine suspended particles.
The regular rising and falling of the sea, influenced by the moon's gravity.
A cloud of tiny water droplets suspended in the atmosphere at or near the earth's surface that limits visibility.
The plants of a particular region, habitat, or geological period.
The animals of a particular region, habitat, or geological period.
A large area of sea partially enclosed by land.
A stretch of swampy or boggy ground.
A small, natural stream of fresh water.
The highest point of a hill or mountain.
A small group of trees, typically without undergrowth.
A wetland area typically dominated by grasses and reeds.
A long, narrow inlet of the sea, especially in Scotland.
A small hill or mound.
A steep or rugged cliff or rock face.
A pleasing view, especially one seen through a long, narrow opening.
A landform at the mouth of a river created by sediment deposits.
A steep cliff, bank, or promontory.
A crack, split, or break in something, particularly in the earth's surface.
Fine sand, clay, or other material carried by running water and deposited as a sediment.
A point of land that extends into a river, lake, or ocean.
An open space in a forest.
A sharp, pointed spine or prong on a plant or branch.
A ridge of jagged rock, coral, or sand just above or below the surface of the sea.
To appear as a shadowy form, especially one that is large or threatening.
A distinct layer of minerals within a rock, often visible and different from the surrounding material.
A structure or place made or chosen by a bird for laying eggs and sheltering its young.
The main body of a ship or other vessel, including the bottom, sides, and deck but not the masts, superstructure, rigging, engines, and other fittings.
